contentrichtext.text: {{BLP sources|date=April 2011}} '''Jacques-Pierre Amette''' (born 1943 in [[Saint-Pierre-sur-Dives]], [[Calvados]]) is a [[France|French]] writer. In 2003 his novel ''[[Brecht's Mistress]]'' (French: ''La Maîtresse de Brecht'') won the [[Prix Goncourt]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/22/movies/arts-briefing.html?src=pm|title=ARTS BRIEFING|last=Gelder|first=Lawrence Van|date=22 October 2003|work=The New York Times|page=2|accessdate=10 April 2011}}</ref> He has been a correspondent for ''[[The New York Times]]'' and a journalist for several French [[newspaper]]s. == Bibliography == * ''Exit'' (1981) * ''Les deux léopards'' (1997) * ''L'Homme du silence'' (1999) * ''[[Brecht's Mistress]]'' (2005 UK) / ''Brecht's Lover'' (2005 US) / ''La Maîtresse de Brecht'' (2003 FR) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Amette, Jacques-Pierre | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = French novelist | DATE OF BIRTH = 1943 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amette, Jacques-Pierre}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Calvados]] [[Category:French novelists]] [[Category:Prix Goncourt winners]] {{France-writer-stub}}
